learning_outcomes.description: Related to spatial/cognitive skills - demonstrate a critical understanding of existing and emerging urban design theory, practice and policy making in Australia and internationally
Related to spatial/cognitive skills - analyse the built urban environment in a way that is cognizant of the social, environmental and cultural implications of urban form and pattern
Related to spatial/cognitive skills - develop an understanding of the urban design process
Related to design/practical skills/communication - review, compile and summarise salient concepts from relevant literature and other sources

Related to design/practical skills/communication - demonstrate the use, both individually and in groups, of urban design skills, including "Place-making" and graphic language, to communicate urban design concepts, logic, and strategy in a professional manner

assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

Weekly software mini-exercises (20%)

At the beginning of each tutorial (x 10), students will present short weekly exercises developed in SketchUp and Illustrator. These tasks focus on core techniques and workflows essential for applying software creatively in urban design. The exercises build technical fluency while encouraging exploration of spatial ideas through digital tools. The exercises will be assessed by the tutor. The student will get one of 3 options for marking: 0 points (the exercise was not presented); 1 point (the exercise is presented but needs more work or is incomplete); 2 points (the exercise is presented and is of good quality). The marks will be added for a total max. of 20 points. (2 points max. per exercise with a total of 10 exercises).

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The overall aim of this assignment is to engage students in representing key elements from the built environment (a site, a street, a building) from a designated urban area in West End. Students will use relevant software and incorporate an evaluation of performance when representing those items and will engage in 'Place-making' when proposing the improvement of a given street in the area. This assessment will be done in a team of 4 students maximum.

The outline of the portfolio is a follow (a template is available on Blackboard Ultra).

Format: A3, 30 pages maximum including references.

01 Context Analysis  

1.1 Introduction: West End and the City

1.2 Context Analysis: West End Neighbourhood

1.3 Space syntax analysis

1.4 Districts, Paths, Edges, Nodes, and Landmarks

1.5 Placemaking Analysis: Vitality, Fit, Access, Control, Sense

1.6 Street Section Current

1.7 Summary + Recommendations

02 Vision

03 Placemaking Proposed

3.1 Key Strategies

3.2 Street Section Proposed

04 Building Performance

05 References 

5.1 Appendix  

If, for whatever reason, you find that your group is not functioning effectively, please contact your Course Coordinator for support.

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The final examination is about the Lecture content (concepts explained in the lecture slides) and the readings assigned every week (and available on Blackboard). A one-hour preparation for the final exam will be done on Week 13. The exam will include short answer question and essay questions.

The breakdown and weighting of questions will be as follows: 5 x essay questions (12 points each) + 5 x short answers (8 points each) = total 100 points

Assessment task to be completed without use of AI or MT: This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(28 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture

Week 1 - Course Introduction (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 2 - Context Analysis in Urban Design (Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 3 - Site visit in West End (Dr. Sebastien Darchen/Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 4 - Stakeholders in urban design (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 5 - City Streets (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 6 - Place-making (Dr. Mubeen Ahmad)

Week 7 - Building performance (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 8 - Design and nightlife economy (Fortitude Valley Precinct) (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 9 - Postmodern Urbanism (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 10 - Urban regeneration through adaptive re-use (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 11 - Urban Design and AI (Dr. Ksenia Nikolaeva)

Week 12 - Preparation for the exam (Dr. Sebastien Darchen)

Week 13 - No lecture
